name: Paul Dourish
background: British-American computer scientist (b. 1966, Glasgow, Scotland). B.Sc. Artificial Intelligence & Computer Science, University of Edinburgh (1989). Ph.D. Computer Science, University College London. Worked at Rank Xerox EuroPARC, Apple Computer, Xerox PARC. Since 2000, Steckler Endowed Chair of Information & Computer Science, UC Irvine; directs Steckler Center for Responsible, Ethical, and Accessible Technology. Fellow AAAS, ACM, BCS. Two-time ACM CSCW Lasting Impact Award (2016,2021); ACM SIGCHI Lifetime Achievement (2025). Author of 3 books, 100+ papers, 19 US patents. h-index 87 (Google Scholar).

principles.name: Context-Aware Computing Critique
principles.description: Context is not a fixed property but dynamically constituted through social interaction; traditional representations fail to capture this fluidity.
principles.falsification: When context-aware computing critique leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Embodied Interaction
principles.description: Interaction design must account for people's embodied, physical presence in the world, not just abstract cognition. Tangible and social computing share foundations in viewing users as situated, social actors.
principles.falsification: When embodied interaction leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Postcolonial Computing
principles.description: HCI must decenter Western assumptions; technology design reflects cultural power dynamics and requires global perspectives.
principles.falsification: When postcolonial computing leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Social Computing & Appropriation
principles.description: Users appropriate technologies in unexpected ways; design must support flexible, emergent use rather than rigid prescriptions.
principles.falsification: When social computing & appropriation leads to worse outcomes than alternatives
